tossups.question: When this quantity is infinite, an object named for Hamel (“HAHM-uhl”) may be replaced by one named for Schauder (“SHAO-der”). This quantity for the degree-k exterior algebra of X equals this quantity for X choose k. Two values for this quantity, rank and nullity, sum to this quantity for the domain of a linear transformation. The (*) “Minkowski–Bouligand” (“min-COW-ski boo-lee-GAHND”) form of this quantity is alternatively named for counting boxes. This quantity equals the cardinality of a basis set. This quantity’s “Hausdorff” form describes the coastline of England’s “fractional” value of this quantity, which characterizes fractals. This quantity equals the number of coordinates in Euclidean space. For 10 points, name this integer geometric quantity denoted d.
tossups.answer: dimension [accept Minkowski–Bouligand dimension or Minkowski dimension or box-counting dimension or fractional dimension or fractal dimension; prompt on cardinality of a basis set before “cardinality” is read by asking “what quantity is defined as the cardinality of a basis set?”] (For a vector space with uncountably infinite dimension, a basis can be referred to as a “Hamel basis,” in contrast to Schauder bases, which do not satisfy the standard requirements for a basis, but are countable.)
tossups.metadata: David Bass, Science - Math> ~27909~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: In a novel, this character starts referring to himself as “Old King Log” after the effects of an “Olympian Mixture” wear off. This character narrates a novel that a woman prophesies will be read nineteen hundred years later. This character lives by the advice “play the fool” and gains the nicknames of “Poor Uncle” and “The Stammerer.” This sickly character, who is dubbed (*) “the God” in a sequel, becomes a ruler after being discovered hiding behind a curtain. In the 1970s, the BBC adapted for TV a 1934 novel titled for this character that opens with the assassination of Caligula. For 10 points, name this Roman emperor, the subject of a Robert Graves novel titled, “I, [this man].”
tossups.answer: Claudius [accept Tiberius Claudius Drusus Nero Germanicus but reject partial answers; accept I, Claudius or Claudius the God]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~25507~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: Note to moderator: read answerline carefully. The Kabeiroi’s (“KAAB-air-roi’s”) father gifted them two of these things for their adamantine chariot. The golden doors and silver posts of Alcinous’s palace were guarded by two of these things. A Colchian princess gave a hero a magic ointment that he rubbed on to defeat some of these things. Poeas’s (“POI-ah’s”) arrow felled one of these things, bleeding golden ichor from its single vein. Jason yoked two of these things that could breathe fire and resembled (*) bulls. A sorceress induces madness in one of these things, which threw boulders to keep the Argo at bay. One of these things guarding Crete was felled after Medea removed its ankle nail. For 10 points, Talos exemplified what mechanical beings made by Olympus’s smith god?
tossups.answer: automatons [accept robots; accept answers indicating specific creations of Hephaestus like bulls or statues or dogs or horses; prompt on self-operating machinery before “mechanical” by asking “created by whom”; prompt on colossi or statues or bronze bulls or horses or watch dogs by asking “created by whom”]
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~27505~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: In this city, Leon Despres led vocal opposition to a mayor and often had his microphone cut off during speeches. Ed Vrdolyak (“vur-DOE-lee-ak”) led 29 city councilmen in opposing another mayor of this city during the so-called “Council Wars.” This city’s mayor Jane Byrne was criticized for occupying a public housing project as a publicity stunt. Judge Julius Hoffman presided over a trial regarding events in this city, during which Bobby (*) Seale was gagged and bound. This city’s first Black mayor was Harold Washington. Abraham Ribicoff criticized the “Gestapo tactics’’ used in handling protests in this city. For 10 points, Richard J. Daley was mayor of what city that hosted the 1968 Democratic National Convention?
tossups.answer: Chicago (The housing project was Cabrini–Green.)

tossups.question: One piece of this type uses the soggetto cavato technique to map an Italian phrase meaning “let me do it” to the solfège (“SOUL-fezh”) syllables “La sol fa re mi.” A 1917 Hans Pfitzner opera dramatizes the events surrounding a type of these works “without a name.” The oldest complete one of these pieces by a single composer was written by Guillaume de Machaut (“ghee-OHM de muh-SHOW”). The cantus firmus “L’homme armé” (“LOHM ar-MAY”) was used in two works of this type by (*) Josquin des Prez (“joe-SCAN deh PRAY”). According to legend, a ban on polyphony (“puh-LIF-uh-nee”) was avoided after Palestrina wrote a piece of this type named for Pope Marcellus II that contains a two-movement Agnus Dei and opens with a Kyrie (“KEE-ree-ay”). For 10 points, name these choral settings of the liturgy of the Eucharist.
tossups.answer: mass [or missa; accept missa sine nomine; reject “requiem mass”] (The Italian phrase is “Lascia fare mi.” The Pfitzner opera is Palestrina.)
tossups.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~27638~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: These devices are “tuned” with signal recycling, which was first implemented in GEO600. Noise curves for these devices plot frequency versus strain measured in inverse-square root hertz. A 2015 “Advanced” expansion to some of these devices added transduction from a type of these devices in which a cavity is formed between two moveable wedged optical flats. The Fabry–Pérot etalon is a type of these devices. A sandstone block in a pool of mercury was central to one of these devices at (*) Case Western Reserve. The existence of the luminiferous aether was debunked with one of these devices by Michelson and Morley. For 10 points, name these devices that measure a namesake optical phenomenon and are the “I” in “LIGO.”
tossups.answer: interferometers [accept laser interferometers; accept Fabry–Pérot interferometers; accept Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory; prompt on gravitational wave detectors by asking “what device is central to gravitational wave detectors?”; prompt on LIGO before read by asking “what device is central to LIGO?”; prompt on lasers by asking “in what devices are lasers being used?”; prompt on Fabry–Pérot etalons] (Advanced LIGO was completed in 2015.)
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~28551~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: Black specks characterize the PGI bananas grown on Fyffes plantations in this archipelago, whose port city of Arguineguin (“ar-GEEN-ee-GEEN”) has become an ad hoc camp for migrants. Apollo 17 astronauts trained near the Fire Mountains in Timanfaya National Park in this archipelago, which is the most populous archipelago in Macaronesia. In a 2019 Romanian film, mobsters travel to this archipelago to learn (*) “silbo,” a whistle language used by its indigenous Guanche people. Half of this archipelago is governed by the province of Las Palmas. These islands south of the Madeira Islands were the last Old World stopping point on Columbus’s voyages. For 10 points, Tenerife is part of what Spanish-controlled islands off the northwest African coast?
tossups.answer: Canary Islands [or Islas Canarias; accept Canaries; prompt on Spain or the Atlantic before “Madeira Islands” is read]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Geography - Europe> ~27928~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: Drawing on this thinker’s writings on ecology, John Bellamy Foster coined the term “metabolic rift.” Members of the September group, which included John Roemer and G. A. Cohen, developed an “analytical” interpretation of this thinker. Silvia Federici argues that witch hunts restructured gender roles during a process this thinker called “primitive (*) accumulation.” David Harvey created a popular lecture series on this thinker’s longest text, which opens by discussing the origin of the value-form of commodities. This thinker argued that a lack of ownership causes workers to be alienated from the products of their labor. For 10 points, name this thinker who critiqued the capitalist economy in Das Kapital.
tossups.answer: Karl Marx
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~28762~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: People of this ethnicity controlled cattle trade in the ubuhake system. This ethnicity’s Nyiginya (“nyee-GEEN-yah”) clan were the ruling mwamis of a kingdom whose last ruler, Kigeli (“kih-guh-lee”) V, lost power in a revolution termed the “Wind of Destruction.” A conflict between rebels of this ethnicity and the MRND was paused by the Arusha Accords. During Operation (*) Turquoise, the French established a “safe zone” for this ethnicity. Paul Rusesabagina (“roo-sess-ah-bah-GEE-nah”) allowed people of this ethnicity fleeing akazu to stay in his hotel. A leader of this ethnicity named Paul Kagame (“kah-GAH-may”) became president after a 1994 event in which Interahamwe (“in-tuhr-ah-HAHM-way”) militias murdered upwards of 500,000 people of this ethnicity. For 10 points, name this ethnic group targeted by the Hutus in the Rwandan Genocide.
tossups.answer: Tutsi [accept Watusi or Watutsi or Abatutsi; prompt on Rwandan; prompt on Bantu; reject “Hutu” or “Twa”]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - World - African> ~28079~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: In a novel by this author, a professor at the Dolphin Hotel leads a character to a house owned by a man possessed by an animal. One of this author’s protagonists works as a human processor named “Calcutec.” One of this author’s characters journeys across the country after receiving a pastoral photograph from his friend “Rat.” In one of this author’s novels, a teenager describes supernatural (*) “Little People” in her autobiographical novel Air Chrysalis. That novel by this author is set in dual alternate realities that converge in a fictionalized version of 1984. A novel by this author opens with Toru Okada looking for his missing cat. For 10 points, name this author of 1Q84 and The Wind-up Bird Chronicle.
tossups.answer: Haruki Murakami (The first line is Dance Dance Dance. The second line is Hard-Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World.)
tossups.metadata: Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~28269~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: A leader of this modern-day country gave a “fire mass” during the “mist hardships” that killed over 20 percent of this country’s population. People fleeing this country’s poor climate moved to Kinmount, Ontario before establishing a colony near Lake Winnipeg. In 2015, this country finally repealed a 400-year-old law that led locals to kill Basque sailors on sight. The (*) Old Covenant reduced the power of an assembly in this country whose participants gave speeches at the Law Rock. The 1784 eruption of Laki in this country resulted in a worldwide cooling. The Treaty of Kiel transferred control of this modern-day country from Norway to Denmark. For 10 points, what island country is governed from the Althing?
tossups.answer: Iceland [accept Ísland]
tossups.metadata: Jeffrey Liu, History - European - 1500-1900> ~28133~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: Stereotypical depictions of women in this medium inspired a series of 69 untitled works in a [emphasize] different medium by Cindy Sherman. This medium was the subject of the first “Pervert’s Guide” by Slavoj Žižek (“SLAH-voy ZHEE-zhek”), which was followed up by with a sequel in this medium called The Pervert’s Guide to Ideology. An essay on the “visual pleasure” of this medium by Laura Mulvey was inspired by John Berger’s series Ways of Seeing, which introduced the concept of the (*) “male gaze.” Artists in this medium who control all aspects of their work are called auteurs (“oh-TURRS”). Works in this medium used to be stored on the flammable material nitrocellulose, which was made into reels. For 10 points, name this medium that includes works called “joints” directed by Spike Lee.
tossups.answer: film [or cinema; or movies; or motion pictures; accept Untitled Film Stills; accept The Pervert’s Guide to Cinema; accept Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema; accept film base; accept documentary or documentaries; prompt on video by asking “what type of work in that medium?”]
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~27904~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: The heat of this process is the leftover background signal once binding is finished in isothermal titration calorimetry. Phase-separated helium isotopes cool a cryogenic refrigerator named for this process. At the infinite limit of this process, a chemical’s activity coefficient reaches a limiting value, its vapor pressure obeys Henry’s law, and its mole fraction approaches (*) zero. An assay standard curve is prepared by performing this process serially in log-fold decrements, pipetting a stock from tube-to-tube. This process names the equation “C1 V1 equals C2 V2.” Colligative properties vanish as this general process is done, since it lowers molality. For 10 points, name this decrease in a solution’s concentration.
tossups.answer: dilution [or diluting; or making it more dilute; prompt on increasing volume or decreasing concentration or decreasing molarity]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~27608~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: The first of twelve “caveats” in the appendix of a collection of these works likens following rules and protecting regulations to binding oneself without rope. In one of these texts, a man slaps his teacher after they conduct a fox’s funeral. Rinzai practitioners of zazen study these texts, which suppress dualist thinking. Joshu (“JOH-shu”) gave the answer “mu,” or “nothing,” when asked about a dog’s (*) nature in one of these texts. Línjì wrote one of these texts that advises killing a certain man if you meet him on the road. The Blue Cliff Record and The Gateless Gate collect these sayings, one of which asks about the sound of one hand clapping. For 10 points, Zen Buddhists meditate on what paradoxical sayings?
tossups.answer: koans [or gōng’àn; prompt on the Blue Cliff Record and Gateless Gate prior to mention; prompt on Buddhist texts]
tossups.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, RMP - Buddhism> ~18786~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: In a novel originally written in this language, a failed robbery leads an artist to seal himself into a house with bricks. In a story written in this language, a character convinces himself he must have hallucinated his wife committing adultery. Detectives who speak English and this language investigate a cardboard chess board found next to a dead body in a novel that is set in Alaska by Michael Chabon (“SHAY-bon”). This language, used to write the original The Magician of (*) Lublin, was used for a story in which the Spirit of Evil tempts a baker to urinate in his dough. For 10 points, Isaac Singer’s story “Gimpel the Fool” was written in what language used for stories about Tevye the Milkman, which inspired Fiddler on the Roof?
tossups.answer: Yiddish [accept The Yiddish Policemen’s Union; reject “Hebrew”]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - American - Misc> ~26144~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: 25 paintings attributed to this artist exhibited at the Orlando Museum of Art were proven to be forgeries. Annina Nosei gave this artist studio space in the basement of her gallery. A drawing by this artist depicts the words “GOD” and “LAW” below a dollar sign. Contemporaries of this artist such as Julian Schnabel are interviewed in a documentary subtitled The Radiant Child. Many of this artist’s early works made in collaboration with (*) Al Diaz feature a prominent copyright symbol. In 2017, a Japanese billionaire paid $110 million for an untitled Neo-Expressionist painting of a black skull by this artist. This artist used the tag SAMO (“same-oh”) for many of his early works. For 10 points, name this pioneer of fine-art graffiti who died at 27 of a heroin overdose.
tossups.answer: Jean-Michel Basquiat [prompt on SAMO before mentioned]

tossups.question: Maze procedures coat this organ in a labyrinth of scar tissue. LVADs (“ell-vads”) are bridges to transplantation to this organ. St. Thomas’ solution is used to induce hyperkalemia before deep hypothermic surgery on this organ. It’s not the kidney, but in 2022, eGenesis transplanted this organ from a gene-edited pig into a human. CABG (“cabbage”) surgery is done on this organ. During surgeries to fix a bundle branch block or (*) Tetralogy of Fallot in this organ, patients may be placed on a bypass machine. Christiaan Barnard performed the first human transplant of this organ. A balloon inflates the arteries that wrap around this organ in a coronary angioplasty. For 10 points, defects in which organ’s sinoatrial valve are corrected by a pacemaker?
tossups.answer: heart [accept aorta; accept coronary arteries; accept mitral valve until read; accept sinoatrial node or SA node until read]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Science - Biology> ~27634~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: In a story by this author, a character thinks “the whole world is growing smaller every day” before being told “You only need to change your direction” and getting eaten by a cat. This author of “A Little Fable” wrote that “the Sirens have a still more fatal weapon than their song, namely their silence.” In a fable by this author, a dying man is told that a door was only for him after a (*) gatekeeper refuses him entrance. In a short story by this author, a man sits in a cage with straw for forty days of fasting before he dies. In a novel by this author of “A Hunger Artist,” a man is told the parable “Before the Law” before being taken to a quarry and shot “like a dog.” For 10 points, name this author who featured Josef K. in the novel The Trial.
tossups.answer: Franz Kafka
tossups.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Short Fiction> ~27538~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: In 1795, Jean-Charles Pichegru unusually ordered one of these actions against the remnants of the Dutch fleet on the Zuiderzee. One of these actions was misdirected due to an ambiguous arm wave from George Bingham, 3rd Earl of Lucan. In The Face of Battle, John Keegan argued this tactic was effective only when it induced panic and explained why 12 separate instances of it against (*) “squares” failed at Waterloo. Napoleon typically employed an artillery barrage before one of these actions was undertaken by his cuirassiers (“kweer-uh-SEERs”). The Earl of Cardigan led one of these events at the Battle of Balaclava that resulted in a 40 percent casualty rate. For 10 points, name this tactic taken by the Light Brigade during the Crimean War.
tossups.answer: cavalry charge [accept answers like a cavalry attack or mounted attack or an attack on horseback; prompt on a charge or offensive or an attack by asking “by what type of troops?”]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~27729~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: Primary and secondary types of these elements are distinguished in secundative languages. In the dative shift, a dative PP is rendered using a second one of these elements. In ergative–absolutive languages, these elements are marked the same way as a noun in an intransitive sentence, by the absolutive case. These elements comes first in the word order of just (*) one percent of languages. Ditransitive verbs like “give” accept two of these elements as arguments. In transitive English sentences, prepositional phrases can be used to render the always-optional “indirect” type of these elements, while their “direct” type is required. For 10 points, name these grammatical elements that receive the actions of verbs.
tossups.answer: objects [accept direct objects or indirect objects]
tossups.metadata: Abhinav Rachakonda, Social Science - Linguistics> ~28487~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: An artist in this city declares “I don’t want to be a tree, I want to be its meaning.” Armanoush visits the tattoo artist Asya in a 2006 novel titled for a “Bastard of [this city].” A story about an artist in this city staring into the horizon to avoid blindness is told to a bookbinder by Olive. An author collected cigarette butts and salt shakers in this city to replicate a fictional (*) oddities collection inspired by the girl Füsun. The Museum of Innocence is set in this city, as is a novel narrated partly by the corpse of a murdered miniaturist who is the uncle of a man named Black. For 10 points, Orhan Pamuk’s novel My Name is Red is set in what Turkish city?
tossups.answer: Istanbul [accept Constantinople or Konstantiniyye; accept The Bastard of Istanbul] (The Bastard of Istanbul is by Elif Shafak.)

bonuses.leadin: This politician’s pioneering Chóngqìng (“choong-CHING”) model instituted sweeping reforms to address unemployment and crime. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this politician who was expelled from the Chinese Communist Party in 2012 after Wáng Lìjūn accused him of involvement in Neil Heywood’s death.

Stories of Bó’s ruthlessness include one where he beat up his father while a member of one of these groups known as United Action. Máo encouraged the formation of these student-led paramilitary groups during the Cultural Revolution.
Prior to his expulsion, Bó was viewed as the main rival of this politician and current Chinese paramount leader.

bonuses.leadin: The binding of this metal and oxygen in myoglobin is tight and non-cooperative, closely following the Michaelis–Menten equation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this metal that gives hemoglobin its red color. This metal’s deficiency causes anemia.
This quantity that measures binding cooperativity is 1 for myoglobin but 2.8 for hemoglobin. This number exponentiates the concentration terms in a modified form of the Michaelis–Menten equation.
Myoglobin binds to oxygen about as tightly as hemoglobin binds to this other gas. Since this gas binds 200 times tighter to hemoglobin than oxygen does, it causes hypoxia with almost no symptoms.
answers: Hill coefficient [prompt on n; prompt on Hill equation or Hill–Langmuir equation]
bonuses.metadata: Sudheer Potru, Science - Biology> ~22144~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: This scientist claimed he “lived like a sage and died like a fool” after he refused to use the restroom at a banquet and died of a bladder or kidney condition. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this scientist who constructed the Uraniborg observatory as Lord of Hven. He wore a brass nose after losing a duel.
Brahe’s equipment was built by craftsmen from this city. A public housing facility founded in 1516 was built in this city by a magnate who rivaled Bartholomew Welser.
Brahe’s unusual guests at Hven included a psychic dwarf named Jeppe who had this profession. People with this profession wore motley as they juggled for kings.
answers: Augsburg (The public housing facility is the Fuggerei, built by Jakob Fugger.)
jesters [or court jesters; or fools; or jokers; or clowns; or buffoons]

bonuses.leadin: In a 2021 film, fictional conductor Lydia Tár attempts to record this symphony, which opens with a trumpet solo in its C-sharp minor Trauermarsch (“TROW-er-marsh”). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this symphony whose fourth movement Adagietto was possibly written as a love letter to its composer’s wife Alma.
In the 2023 film Maestro, this man reconciles with his wife Felicia after conducting Mahler 2 in Ely Cathedral. This American conductor also wrote the music to West Side Story.
A conductor from this country taught Bradley Cooper how to conduct like Bernstein for Maestro. In a masterclass, Tár imitates a pianist from this country who often hummed while playing Bach.
answers: Symphony No. 5 by Gustav Mahler [accept Gustav Mahler’s Fifth Symphony or equivalents]
Canada (The conductor is Yannick Nézet-Séguin and the pianist is Glenn Gould.)

bonuses.leadin: In 2024, Julian Schilliger co-won a machine learning challenge named for this mountain. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mountain near Naples, whose eruption in 79 CE buried scrolls in Herculaneum in ash.

Other scrolls recovered from the library in Herculaneum contained fragments from this philosopher’s On Nature. This philosopher mused on ethics in his Letter to Menoeceus (“men-oh-EE-see-us”) and ran a school in Athens open to women.

The machine learning challenge was inspired by Brent Searles’s successful deciphering of verses from a scroll of this Book of the Old Testament. Chapters 17 to 26 of this book are often called the Holiness Code and include rules about blasphemy.
bonuses.metadata: Abhinav Rachakonda, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~23217~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Pulitzer Prize for Drama controversies, for 10 points each.
parts: The Pulitzer board refused to give the 1963 prize to this Edward Albee play about George and Martha’s party due to its explicit nature.

The New York Drama Critics’ Circle created its own award after a Pulitzer went to Zoe Akins’s adaptation of The Old Maid, a novella by this author who depicted Newland Archer going to the theater in another novel.

The Pulitzer board encouraged one jury to give the prize to Cat on a Hot Tin Roof rather than their first choice, this author’s The Flowering Peach. Joe Bonaparte chooses boxing over the violin in this author’s play Golden Boy.
answers: Edith Wharton [or Edith Newbold Jones] (Newland Archer appears in The Age of Innocence.)
bonuses.metadata: Joseph Krol, Literature - American - Drama> ~23358~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: California jurors are reminded to make their conclusions “beyond a reasonable doubt” in cases relying solely on this type of evidence. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this indirect type of evidence that relies on inferences, such as seeing an accused thief enter a bank at the time of a robbery, instead of seeing the robbery firsthand.

Circumstantial evidence is often used to establish this two-word term, a defendant’s state of mind when committing an actus reus, or guilty act. Criminal liability is determined based on these states of mind.
Circumstantial evidence is differentiated from hearsay, which is information overheard by these people who are called to testify during trials.
answers: witnesses [accept specific types of witnesses such eyewitnesses or expert witnesses]

bonuses.leadin: Koji Kondo unknowingly added a recording of one of these people to the original Fire Temple soundtrack in The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these people, the first of whom was Bilal ibn Rabah. Loudspeakers assist these people in performing the adhan and iqamah five times a day.
Muezzins typically perform the adhan from a balcony on these tall towers attached to mosques.

Prior to timepieces, muezzins were assisted by muwaqqit, astronomers who determined when prayers were to be held, such as this prayer held at dawn but prior to sunrise. This first prayer of the day marks the beginning of fasting in Ramadan.

bonuses.leadin: A man is told “you can’t do it here, it’s not the place!” after he claims he is going to this place while standing by the Neva River. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this place that Svidrigailov (“svid-ree-GUY-loff”) announces that he is “going to” in Crime and Punishment before shooting himself.
America was dubbed an “eternal union” among “civilizations” that “find pleasure in the spilling of blood” by this author of Crime and Punishment.
In another Dostoyevsky novel, this eldest Karamazov brother plans to escape Siberia and travel to America with Grushenka after being convicted of his father’s murder.
answers: America [accept the United States of America; accept the United States or US or USA]

bonuses.leadin: This quantity scales with temperature to the three-halves in gases and with temperature to the first in liquids. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this proportionality constant between the time derivative and Laplacian of concentration. This quantity is therefore analogous to conductivity when the heat equation is used to describe mass transfer.
In most solids, though, diffusivity has the same temperature dependence as this empirical law. It is usually written as [read slowly] “k equals A times e to the negative E-sub-a over R T.”
Diffusivity is linear with temperature for ions diffusing through semiconductors like this element. This metalloid is by far the most common semiconductor used in microelectronics.
answers: mass diffusivity [or diffusion coefficient; or diffusion constant; prompt on D; prompt on diffusion]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~22822~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: A 2018 constitutional amendment ended the special legal status for the five million people who lived in this country’s Federally Administered Tribal Areas. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country where a deep state known as “The Establishment” has clashed with its PTI party.

The Pakistani army launched a years-long anti-terrorism campaign in the Tribal Areas after a 2014 massacre in Peshawar carried out by the Pakistani branch of this group. This group now rules Afghanistan.
Disputes in the Tribal Areas are still routinely resolved by jirgas, assemblies of this ethnic group. This second-largest ethnic group in Pakistan is the most populous in Afghanistan.
answers: Taliban [accept Pakistani Taliban; or Tehreek-e-Taliban-e-Pakistan; prompt on Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan or TTP]

bonuses.leadin: This composer’s fondness for adapting plays set in Spain resulted in his operas Don Carlo, Ernani, and La forza del destino, which all feature characters named Don Carlo. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Italian composer better known for Rigoletto and La traviata.

In this Verdi opera set in Spain, Azucena (“ah-zoo-CHAY-nuh”) accidentally threw the wrong baby into the fire, meaning the title character Manrico is actually his rival’s brother. This opera contains the “Anvil Chorus.”
This first name is shared by the soprano lead in Il trovatore and Don Carlo’s sister in La forza del destino. Beethoven wrote three operatic overtures titled for this true name of Fidelio.

bonuses.leadin: A type of orbit described by this word is exemplified by irregular satellites like Triton and Phoebe post-capture. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this word that also describes the aspect of the rotation of Venus that causes its solar days to be shorter than its sidereal (“sy-DEER-ee-al”) days.
Prior to its capture by this eighth planet from the Sun, Triton likely originated in the Kuiper Belt, which contains objects that are distinguished as “trans” this planet.

Triton’s capture may have occurred during an instance of this general process. This process is central to the Nice model, in which the giant planets exited their initial compact configuration via this process.
answers: retrograde (No, Mercury is not currently in retrograde.)
Neptune [accept trans-Neptunian objects] (All Kuiper Belt objects are trans-Neptunian objects.)
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, Science - Astronomy> ~23831~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: Visitors were greeted by burned and destroyed books at a 2011 exhibition titled for this phrase by Victoria Noorthoorn. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this five-word phrase that ends the refrain of a poem that claims wearing green is “changed, changed utterly” by the deaths of men “met at the close of day.”
Noorthoorn took the title of A Terrible Beauty is Born from “Easter, 1916,” a poem by this Irish author of the poem “The Second Coming.”

Noorthorn’s exhibition also highlighted epigrams of this author, such as “The function of the artist is to invent, not to chronicle.” This author mused “each man kills the thing he loves” in a poem titled for where he was imprisoned.
answers: Oscar Wilde [or Oscar Fingal O’Flahertie Wills Wilde] (The first quote is from The Picture of Dorian Gray. The second is from “The Ballad of Reading Gaol.”)
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - British - Other

bonuses.leadin: A system’s bound states correspond to the imaginary poles of a matrix describing this process. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process whose “amplitudes” are the elements of that unitary matrix. A cross section typically measures the probability of this process occurring.

This scientist approximated the scattering amplitude as proportional to the Fourier transform of the potential. He is the alphabetically [emphasize] prior namesake of an approximation that treats the wavefunctions of nuclei and electrons separately.
This type of scattering named for a Lord explains why the sky is blue.
answers: scattering [prompt on word forms of deflections or word forms of collisions] (Elements of the S-matrix are scattering amplitudes. More generally, a cross section is the probability of any given process occurring in a collision of two particles.)
Max Born (The approximations are the Born approximation and the Born–Oppenheimer approximation, respectively.)
bonuses.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~23795~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: The Kiowa associated these things with horses, as seen with the winged Mankayia and the Silver Horn Calendar’s Red Horse. For 10 points each:
parts: The cowboy Pecos Bill lassoed and rode what thing like a wild bronco? Particularly extreme examples of these things have been described as a “Dead Man Walking” by some tribes.
The Iroquois saw twisters as “Flying Heads” engaged in this behavior, also practiced by wendigos. Demeter performed this action on Pelops at Tantalus’s feast.
The Mapuche envisioned the twister as this animal, one of which outran a related animal to bring death to the Zulu. A gluttonous Demeter turned Ascalabus into this animal.
answers: eating humans [accept synonyms such as eating people; accept cannibalism; accept eating shoulders; prompt on eating meat; prompt on eating or insatiable hunger by asking “what do they want to eat?”]
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - World Mythology> ~22713~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: A recent book by historian Daniel Kalder reviews books such as Doctrine and Action by people in this title role. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this role, the subject of a 2019 book by Frank Dikotter titled “How To Be [One of These People].” In Rome, Fabius was appointed to this temporary role in 221 BCE during the Second Punic War.
This dictator was described by Kalder as “the Bill Bryson of dialectical materialism.” This man’s Foundations of Leninism outlines the political system of his predecessor.
This dictator schemed to build a statue that would open a different page of his book Rukhnama or Book of the Soul each night.
answers: dictators [reject synonyms such as “leader” or “fascist”] (Doctrine and Action was written by Oliveira Salazar.)
Joseph Stalin [or Joseph Vissarionovich Stalin; or Ioseb Besarionis dze Jughashvili]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~22872~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about artists who made images of animals they had never seen in person, for 10 points each.
parts: This artist notoriously depicted a rhinoceros’s skin like a sheet of armor in a woodcut. This master of the German Renaissance also made Knight, Death and the Devil.

This British artist’s portrait of a dingo looks more like that of a large dog. He is better known for his more accurate paintings of horses, such as a 1762 painting of the Marquess of Rockingham’s racehorse Whistlejacket.

This French artist claimed his painting Tiger In A Tropical Storm was based on jungle scenes he witnessed in Mexico. This “naïve” artist exhibited his painting The Dream at the 1910 Salon des Indépendants.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~22559~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: This woman sent a letter to the New York Times complaining about being called “Mrs. Putnam” rather than her birth name. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this woman who celebrated other women pioneers in her field in her memoir The Fun of It. This woman died en route to Howland Island.
This close friend of Amelia Earhart filed for a piloting permit after a flight with her. Following the death of her husband in 1945, this former First Lady served as ambassador to the UN.
Earhart was a member of the National Woman’s Party, whose members included these protestors who picketed the White House during the Woodrow Wilson presidency.
answers: Silent Sentinels [accept the Sentinels of Liberty; prompt on suffragettes or suffragists]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - American - 1865-1945> ~22136~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

bonuses.leadin: The narrator of one poem declares “sweet mother, I cannot weave on the loom” because of this goddess. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this goddess “of the spangled mind,” whose car is drawn by “quick sparrows over the black earth.” A “Hymn to” this Greek goddess implores her “You be my ally.”
The “Hymn to Aphrodite” was written by this woman from Lesbos whose namesake type of love has become a general term for love between women.
This much later poet who wrote the epic “Helen in Egypt” was stylistically inspired by Sappho in early poems like “Oread.”
bonuses.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~22678~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: David O’Keefe caused inflation in this modern-day country in the 1870s by using Western tools to fabricate the Rai stones. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country of the Pacific that includes states such as Yap and Pohnpei. This is also the name of a region that includes the Marshall Islands.
The Micronesian island of Pulap is home to Weriyeng, a school for teaching this skill. “Papa” Mau Piailug, one of the teachers at the school, made headlines in the 1970s for demonstrating this skill.
Tourists engaging in this activity in the FSM’s Truk (“chook”) Lagoon can explore the ruins of a Japanese ghost fleet. A rebreather is sometimes used in this activity.
answers: traditional navigation [or traditional wayfinding; or non-instrument wayfinding; or open-ocean voyaging; or pwo or etak; prompt on answers like canoeing or sailing with “what skill is needed when doing that?”]
scuba diving [or recreational diving; prompt on recreational diving or swimming; reject “snorkeling”]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~23502~ <Editor: Michael Bentley
